body_content.explanation: a heavy metal object, usually shaped like a cross with curved arms, on a strong rope or chain, that is dropped from a boat into the water to prevent the boat from moving away:
examples: We dropped anchor (= lowered the anchor into the water) and stopped.
It was time to weigh anchor (= pull up the anchor and sail away).

body_content.explanation: someone or something that gives support when needed:
examples: She was my anchor when things were difficult for me.
This treaty has been called the anchor (= strongest part) of their foreign policy.

body_content.explanation:
an 
anchorman US  or 
anchorwoman US
the member of a team who goes last in a relay (= a type of race between two or more teams in which each person in the team runs or swims part of the race):
examples: As anchor in the relay, he closed a 4-metre gap to seize victory.
Thorpe swam the anchor leg for Australia.

body_content.explanation: to lower an anchor into the water in order to stop a boat from moving away
to make something or someone stay in one position by fastening him, her, or it firmly:
examples: We anchored ourselves to the rocks with a rope.

body_content.explanation: to act as the anchorman or anchorwoman of a programme:
examples: She will anchor the new morning news show.

body_content.explanation: to be the member of a team who goes last in a relay (= a type of race between two or more teams in which each person in the team runs or swims part of the race):
examples: He won the 100-and 200-metre sprints and anchored two winning relay teams.
"Klete anchored that race perfectly," Phelps said. "His swim was the reason we won."
